ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Writing formal papers, use formal languages
Thru touching on various topics, I developed a deeper understanding of contemporary Japanese politics, economics, science, and culture.
I have not only learned Japanese language but also learned Japanese culture and business as well.
Japanese listening skills, vocabulary for talking about current affairs, summarizing texts.
Reading and expressing opinions regarding real world topics through newspaper articles or speeches.

While I can't say I learned anything "new" in this class, it was a good chance to review concepts I had learned in earlier Japanese classes. This was helpful because I think even though these nuances were familiar, such as "no" vs "koto" or transitive vs intransitive, I did not really understand how to use them the first time around.
Great way to improve your Japanese skills and understanding of Japanese culture and current affairs.

I gained knowledge about a new world of Japanese, starting with newspaper articles. Learning Japanese has been very concrete for me (learning how to read, speak, etc.), but being able to read between the lines and understand underlying thoughts abstractly is something I never did until this class. I believe  that this class is very good to take to progress into the Advanced Japanese realm.
I brushed up on my Japanese skills in preparation to go to Japan for my postgraduate year. I especially got opportunities to practice having more abstract conversations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: readings of different articles, use of challenging tv drama;
Weakness: personally I don't like too political topics

This course emphasizes students making comments and arguments about news topics. 
Watching Hanzawa Naoki also serves as another effective tool to train to listen, speak and understand Japanese culture.

To be improved:
The course spends a too long time on free discussion, not all students can be engaged in all topics. 
I personally expect the training in Japanese college-level essay writing could be.
We can share different options on different topics such as social issues, politics, gender discrimination, pandemics, sports, and games which are very interesting.
Strength: good chance/environment at Yale to practice Japanese. Weakness: no syllabus, slightly unorganized.

I believe the course could have been more structured. Particularly, the topics we discuss in class were not disclosed to us beforehand (i.e. no syllabus), which makes preparation for the class impossible. It might have been done on purpose, but this is not so effective, as some of us who have lower command of language might not have enough time to get used to the new or more technical vocabularies pertaining to said topics. This hampered my learning pace.

The class materials were articles from the news or a transcript from famous speeches. Those are great choices. However, compared to other advanced language classes (say Chinese), their worksheets are much more comprehensive with highlights on common useful phrases, topic-specific vocabularies, and idioms. As a non-native, these are hard to identify. Having just these "aids" being prepared would have helped immensely with the learning process. Contrastly, I had to create my own vocab list, and most of the words or phrases in that list were not even frequently used in the first place - a lot of wasted efforts here.      

We also did not get timely feedback on the weekly assignments. It was quite difficult to improve without such feedback.

I think that the course was difficult to keep organized. This was mostly because the class had students of many different levels, but it felt like there was not much of a progression or sense of where the course was headed. We read articles, watched a TV series, and had chances to practice using Japanese, but one major difficulty was that we did not receive individualized feedback until about the last month of class. If there was more personalized corrections in homework, I think I would have been more aware of the mistakes I made.

Weaknesses is just that there aren't enough higher level Japanese classes, so everyone above a certain point are all crammed in the same class. 
Strengths are the relevance of present day material.
Not enough speaking practice

Strengths: Not super difficult (you won't be assigned hours of homework) relative to other Japanese courses at Yale. 
- Also you get to watch Hanzawa Naoki in-depth, which is an amazing show that I believe everyone should watch.

Weaknesses: It's nothing on the professor, but the people who are in the class are sometimes at very different Japanese skill level, which can lead to a discrepancy between students. Many grad students and heritage speakers take this course, so the type of Japanese learning that is needed for each student varies.

Nakamura-sensei designs the course to be highly malleable to the needs and wants of students. This is fantastic for a wide variety of reasons, but I think it may have overwhelmed her ability to evaluate our academic performance. We didn't have much in the way of exams or other evaluations, and we didn't get very many grades back. Overall, though, I'd take this tradeoff any day because the adaptability was great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, great chances to improve your proficient Japanese to business/academic Japanese

It depends. The coordination of this course is not easy as student levels all vary. While I know that JAPN provides a tailored tutor course for students pursuing advanced Japanese, I will recommend to students who are not expecting an intense improvement in Japanese to take this course.
Yes. It is not a boring language study class. We can have a lot of discussions to share options with peers which I love this part very much.
Sure.
Yes, if you are already adept to Japanese and just want to practice opinionating in Japanese.
I would recommend this course to students seeking to practice Japanese, not to students who expect to learn new things about Japanese.
Yes, always!
Yes, very interesting and effective for learning. Fun and original assignments.
Yes!! Especially for those who want to improve their Japanese to higher levels.
Yes. If you are at nearly any level of Japanese past the 150/151 level, Nakamura-sensei will try her best to let you advance in Japanese skills at a pace that's best for you.
